abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Acrokeratoelastoidosis (AKE) is a rare autosomal dominant hereditary skin disease characterized by small, round-oval, flat-topped keratotic papules on the palms, soles and dorsal aspect of hands or feet. The causative gene for AKE remains unidentified. This study aims to identify the causative gene of AKE and explore the underlying biological mechanisms. A large, three-generation Chinese family exhibiting classic AKE symptoms was identified. A genome-wide linkage analysis and whole-exome sequencing were employed to determine the causative gene. shRNA knockdown in human skin fibroblasts and CRISPR/Cas9 knockout in HEK293T cells were utilized to assess gene functions in the progression of elastic fiber biosynthesis. The linkage analysis identified a susceptibility region between rs7296765 to rs10784618 on chromosome 12. Whole-exome sequencing confirmed a splicing mutation of 1101 + 1 <jats:italic>G</jats:italic> > <jats:italic>A</jats:italic> in the <jats:italic>CCDC91</jats:italic> gene, resulting in exon 11 skipping and a subsequent 59-amino-acid-residue loss (residues L309-Q367del). Further functional analysis revealed distended Golgi cisternae, cytoplasmic vesicle accumulation, and lysosome presence. Immnunostaining of si-CCDC91-HSF cells demonstrated tropoelastin accumulation in the Golgi and abnormal extracellular aggregates. There are no significant changes in Fibrillin-1 microfibril assembly and lysyl oxidase activity. The findings strongly suggest that the protein product of the <jats:italic>CCDC91</jats:italic> gene plays a crucial role in elastin transport. This discovery enhances our understanding of <jats:italic>CCDC91</jats:italic>’s function and broadens the known pathogenic mechanisms of AKE.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: We declare that we have no financial and personal relationships with other people or organizations that can inappropriately influence our work.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: All clinical details and images have been obtained with the patient’s informed consent. This study has been approved by the Ethics Committee of Shanghai Dermatology Hospital.

title: A mutation in CCDC91, Homo sapiens coiled-coil domain containing 91 protein, cause autosomal-dominant acrokeratoelastoidosis
